q1.value: Direct Replication of a research claim from Woltin et al, 2011, in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology

q3.value: We selected the claim that the detailed, concrete processing style associated with low power should facilitate empathic concern (Statement 2), which reflects "In three experiments inducing a detailed versus abstract processing style using perceptual (Experiment 1), motivational (Experiment 2), and social (Experiment 3) manipulations, we found that empathic concerns are enhanced in contexts associated with a more detailed processing style (i.e., local perceptual scope, prevention motivation, and low power, respectively)" (Statement 1), as found in the paper's abstract. The claim (from Experiment 3 in the original manuscript) is tested by an ANOVA test using the power priming condition (low/high power) as the independent variable and empathic concern as the dependent variable (Statement 3), which resulted in power priming influencing participants' empathic concern, F(1,34) = 5.76, p = .022, partial eta squared = .15 - participants reported greater empathic concern when primed with low power (Statement 4).

q4.value: Participants primed with “low power” will report greater empathic concern, as measured with the empathic concern scale.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study consists of a two group, between-subjects design with 1 factor (priming) and 2 levels (powerful or powerless).

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the powerful or powerless prime condition. This random assignation will be achieved through the random generation of a subject ID through the Millisecond web platform. Even-numbered subject IDs will be allocated to the powerful condition, while odd-numbered subject IDs will be allocated to the powerless condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through the online data collection platform Prolific Academic. Participants will be paid at a rate of £6 per hour. To be eligible for participation, participants must be at least 18 years old, identify as male, have at least a 90% approval rating from previous studies on Prolific, and must have English as a first language. This screening will be completed using Prolific’s automated participant screening. 

Participants will be excluded if they fail to provide full data on any of the measures, if they fail the attention or suspicion checks, or if they respond with a valid reason for exclusion of their data (see Measures below).

q13.value: To have 90% power to detect 75% of the original effect size, a sample size of 114 (57 per group) participants is required. The criteria for replication is an effect in the same direction as the original study and a p-value < 0.05. If the original result is not replicated in the first data collection, a second data collection of 138 additional participants will be carried out so that the total sample size is 252 (126 per group). If a second data collection is carried out, it will be tested if the original result replicates in the pooled sample of the first and second data collection.

q14.value:
Power calculations were done in accordance with the guidelines of the Social Sciences Replication Project (SSRP). The first round of data collection achieves 90% power to detect 75% of the original effect size. The pooled sample, if necessary after testing the effect on the first round of data collection, achieves 90% power to detect 50% of the original effect size.

The power analysis for this replication is stored in the OSF project associated with this replication attempt, in the power analysis component.

q15.value: Data collection will stop once 57 participants in each group with completed data are collected, and the analysis will be run.  If the replication is not successful, the second round of data collection will commence and will stop once 126 participants per group with completed data are collected in total (including the initial sample).

question.value: Prime condition - participants will be randomly assigned to either the powerful prime condition or the powerless prime condition.  Both are a word completion task with either dominant or submissive words, the same as used in Woltin et al. (2011).  Each list consists of 40 words, where 20 words are neutral and are the same in both lists, and 20 words correspond to either the powerful or powerless condition.

Empathic concern - after the word completion task, participants will complete the Empathic Concern Scale (ECS), which are the following 7 questions scored on a 5 point Likert scale, with 1 anchored as “does not describe me well”, and 5 as “describes me very well”.

When I see someone being taken advantage of, I feel kind of protective towards them.
When I see someone being treated unfairly, I sometimes don't feel very much pity for them.
I often have tender, concerned feelings for people less fortunate than me.
I would describe myself as a pretty soft-hearted person.
Sometimes I don't feel very sorry for other people when they are having problems.
Other people's misfortunes do not usually disturb me a great deal.
I am often quite touched by things that I see happen.
An ECS score will be computed by taking the average score of the Likert items (items 2, 5, and 6 are reverse-coded), as in the original study.
As in the original study, an ANOVA will be conducted with one predictor (prime condition) with 2 levels (powerful vs powerless) and one dependent variable: the ECS.

q20.value: There is no expected transformation required for this analysis, other than calculating overall ECS scores (detailed previously).

q21.value: The replication will be considered successful if there is an effect in the same direction of the original study with a p-value < 0.05.  For this replication, it is predicted that participants primed with low power will show higher empathic concern.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail to provide complete data for all measures, or if they fail the attention or suspicion checks. Participants will also be excluded if they indicate that their data should be excluded from analyses (and provide a valid reason for doing so).

q23.value: If subjects fail to provide complete data on all measures, then they will be excluded from analyses (and resampled accordingly).

q24.value:
We will conduct a mixed-effects meta-analysis of the effect using pooled data from the original study and our replication (using the lme4 R package), ECS scores as the dependent variable, prime condition as a fixed effect, and study (i.e., original vs. replication) as a random effect in order to determine whether an overall effect is present. 

In the event that no effect is found in the replication/meta-analysis analyses, it may be of interest to quantify evidence for the null by calculating Bayes Factors for both the original and replication effects, as well as using Bayesian meta-analysis in brms to quantify overall evidence for the null.

attributes.title: Response structure as an influence on shared performance

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Response structure and group identity as influences on shared performance choices

sample.value: We will collect data on 40 participants (ie 20 pairs)

analyses.value:
In the previous AABB study, we focused on the (t-test) comparison of participant switch trials (AB & BA) and participant repeat trials (AA & BB) for principal DVs. This will be repeated.
We will use t-test comparisons of sequence contagion (prepotent associate and short repetition dimensions) for compare the symmetric and asymmetric schedules, in particular comparing the dominant vs subservient partner.
We will use t-test comparisons of response behaviours for the first, in-group or no-group production compared with the final outgroup production.

outliers.value:
Any response choices outside the defined production range (eg "11" from the set '1-10") are not included as response trials (though noted separately as choice violations). Response absences (failures to generate a choice on cue) are also recorded but cannot to included in the sequence.
If any participant fails to meaningfully engage with the attempt to generate unpredictable sequences (eg by choosing the same number on 33% or more of productions) will be excluded.

dependent.value:
The joint cognition task asks pairs of participants to choose numbers at a regular intervals (every 1.5 seconds) and according to a specified response schedule. Participants are instructed to try and make their response sequence as random (as unpredictable as possible). The raw data are the number choices made by individuals and the pair - these will be analysed for evidence of order or structure.
Towse & Neil (1998) identify 4 key dimensions of response choice (equality of response usage / prepotent associates / short repetitions / long repetitions) and Towse et al (2016) and Maehara et al (2019) focus on joint cognition principally by measuring "R" / "RNG" & "A" / "RD1" as indicates of the first 3 of these, along with associated scores (specifically, plots of first-order frequencies and repetition lag profiles). These will form the primary DVs

conditions.value:
40 participants (20 pairs) will;

1) Complete a paired response production in an AABB schedule (200 responses)
2) Afterwards, they will complete an asymmetric AAB and ABB schedule (100 responses in each) where one participant chosen at random will dominate choices and later the other participant will
3) Afterwards, participants will be assigned to outgroups following the "scavenger hunt alliance" scenario (Pinter & Greenwald, 2004) and an AABB schedule employed.

Thus, symmetric / asymmetric production schedule will be a within-participant condition.
And an outgroup condition will be compared to the initial, baseline in-group condition as a within-participant condition.

This study does not ask for individual response choices (in contrast to Towse et al and Maehara et al). If we need to source individual baseline data to compare with our joint productions, we will create a between-participant condition for study comparison.

attributes.title: Homophobic and Transphobic Voting Behavior in Established Democracies

q1.value: Homophobic and Transphobic Voting Behavior in Established Democracies

q5.value: We thank the UNC LGBTQ Representation and Rights Research Initiative for generous financial support.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Are LGBT candidates penalized on Election Day? Most of the existing literature on minority candidates has developed in the American context and has traditionally focused on gender and race. Recent work shows that LGBT candidates performed at least as well as straight counterparts in the 2015 UK election (Magni and Reynolds 2018). While this work has produced counter-intuitive findings, it is based on observational data. Furthermore, most of the existing work is based on single-country studies.

q16.value: General 1. Overall, voters penalize gay candidates, but we expect the penalization to be limited 2. Voters penalize transgender candidates 3. Voters penalize HIV positive candidates a. But voters penalize candidates who have been HIV positive since birth less than HIV positive candidates Subset analysis 1. Conservative voters penalize gay, transgender, and HIV positive candidates 2. Progressive voters do not penalize gay candidates 3. Progressive voters penalize transgender candidates, but we expect the penalization to be limited 4. Even progressive voters penalize HIV positive candidates Causal mechanisms 1. Progressive voters vote for gay candidates because they (1) are perceived as more liberal and (2) are seen as a sign of social progress 2. Progressive voters penalize transgender and HIV positive candidates because of electorability concerns 3. Conservative voters penalize gay, transgender, and HIV positive candidates because they represent a threat to traditional values 4. Conservative voters penalize transgender and HIV positive candidates because of prejudice (neighbor question) 5. Regardless of political ideology, voters who have an LGBT family member or friend penalize gay, transgender, and HIV-positive candidates less

q17.value: We develop a conjoint experiment in which we present survey respondents with six pairs of individuals that the respondent’s favorite party may choose as candidates in the respondent’s district in parliamentary elections. We randomize the components of the attributes and the order of the attributes of the profiles. More specifically, we vary candidate attributes related to sexual orientation, gender identity, health, religion, race, education, age, and political experience. We then ask respondents to indicate which candidate they are more likely to support with both choice-based and rating-based questions. We also ask a series of questions to test the causal mechanisms explaining why respondents may be more or less supportive of gay, transgender, and HIV-positive candidates.

q18.value: United States, United Kingdom, Germany, New Zealand

Even-numbered subject IDs will be allocated to the powerful condition, while odd-numbered subject IDs will be allocated to the powerless condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through the online data collection platform Prolific Academic. Participants will be paid at a rate of £6 per hour. To be eligible for participation, participants must be at least 18 years old, identify as male, have at least a 90% approval rating from previous studies on Prolific, and must have English as a first language. This screening will be completed using Prolific’s automated participant screening. 

Participants will be excluded if they fail to provide full data on any of the measures, if they fail the attention or suspicion checks, or if they respond with a valid reason for exclusion of their data (see Measures below).

q13.value: To have 90% power to detect 75% of the original effect size, a sample size of 114 (57 per group) participants is required. The criteria for replication is an effect in the same direction as the original study and a p-value < 0.05. If the original result is not replicated in the first data collection, a second data collection of 138 additional participants will be carried out so that the total sample size is 252 (126 per group). If a second data collection is carried out, it will be tested if the original result replicates in the pooled sample of the first and second data collection.

q14.value:
Power calculations were done in accordance with the guidelines of the Social Sciences Replication Project (SSRP). The first round of data collection achieves 90% power to detect 75% of the original effect size. The pooled sample, if necessary after testing the effect on the first round of data collection, achieves 90% power to detect 50% of the original effect size.

The power analysis for this replication is stored in the OSF project associated with this replication attempt, in the power analysis component.

q15.value: Data collection will stop once 57 participants in each group with completed data are collected, and the analysis will be run.  If the replication is not successful, the second round of data collection will commence and will stop once 126 participants per group with completed data are collected in total (including the initial sample).

question.value: Prime condition - participants will be randomly assigned to either the powerful prime condition or the powerless prime condition.  Both are a word completion task with either dominant or submissive words, the same as used in Woltin et al. (2011).  Each list consists of 40 words, where 20 words are neutral and are the same in both lists, and 20 words correspond to either the powerful or powerless condition.

Empathic concern - after the word completion task, participants will complete the Empathic Concern Scale (ECS), which are the following 7 questions scored on a 5 point Likert scale, with 1 anchored as “does not describe me well”, and 5 as “describes me very well”.

When I see someone being taken advantage of, I feel kind of protective towards them.
When I see someone being treated unfairly, I sometimes don't feel very much pity for them.
I often have tender, concerned feelings for people less fortunate than me.
I would describe myself as a pretty soft-hearted person.
Sometimes I don't feel very sorry for other people when they are having problems.
Other people's misfortunes do not usually disturb me a great deal.
I am often quite touched by things that I see happen.
An ECS score will be computed by taking the average score of the Likert items (items 2, 5, and 6 are reverse-coded), as in the original study.
As in the original study, an ANOVA will be conducted with one predictor (prime condition) with 2 levels (powerful vs powerless) and one dependent variable: the ECS.

q20.value: There is no expected transformation required for this analysis, other than calculating overall ECS scores (detailed previously).

q21.value: The replication will be considered successful if there is an effect in the same direction of the original study with a p-value < 0.05.  For this replication, it is predicted that participants primed with low power will show higher empathic concern.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail to provide complete data for all measures, or if they fail the attention or suspicion checks. Participants will also be excluded if they indicate that their data should be excluded from analyses (and provide a valid reason for doing so).

q23.value: If subjects fail to provide complete data on all measures, then they will be excluded from analyses (and resampled accordingly).

q24.value:
We will conduct a mixed-effects meta-analysis of the effect using pooled data from the original study and our replication (using the lme4 R package), ECS scores as the dependent variable, prime condition as a fixed effect, and study (i.e., original vs. replication) as a random effect in order to determine whether an overall effect is present. 

In the event that no effect is found in the replication/meta-analysis analyses, it may be of interest to quantify evidence for the null by calculating Bayes Factors for both the original and replication effects, as well as using Bayesian meta-analysis in brms to quantify overall evidence for the null.

attributes.title: Voluntariness and Controllability - The Effects of Perceived Risk Characteristics on Willingness to Pay

q1.value: Voluntariness and Controllability - The Effects of Perceived Risk Characteristics on Willingness to Pay

q3.value:
This study investigates the effects of perceived psychotropic risk characteristics on willingness-to-pay (WTP) to reduce the fatality risk posed by a given hazard, as well as the level of consensus on perceived risk characteristics across a population.  Specifically, this study will focus on the effects of perceptions of "voluntariness"; the extent to which an individual is exposed to a risk voluntarily, and "controllability"; the extent to which an individual can, once exposed to a risk, avoid the consequences of the risk being realized through skill or diligence (from here forward these will be referred to as “voluntary factor” and “control factor”, respectively).  Although previous literature has assessed the effects of psychotropic risk characteristics on WTP to reduce a hazard, none have focused specifically on voluntary and control factors. It is useful to ascertain the effects of these factors individually, due to the implications they have for the funding of public health policies seeking to reduce the risk of hazards with widely varied perceptions among populations (consider the differences between an individual’s attitudes towards pancreatic cancer and opioid overdose).  Additionally, previous literature has not assessed the level to which individuals within a population agree about the characteristics of different hazards, a gap which this study aims to fill. Assessing this will be useful as, if consensus among a population is low, this would highlight the subjective nature of such risk characteristics, potentially indicating that perceptions could change over time, as noted in Fox-Glassman & Weber (2016), or with different levels of information, which would have implications for funding and policy decisions.

The experimental design for this paper is based off of Savage (1993) with a few key differences.  First, this study will modify Savage's questionnaire to include questions directly assessing perceptions of voluntary and control factors, allowing for the addition of 2 variables to the models employed by Savage.  Second, to avoid invoking the charitable context of Savage's questionnaire, and the potential bias that may come with it, the questionnaire for this study asks individuals to allocate a budget in a referendum context between mitigating the hazards, rather than asking them to split a donation between the hazards.

q4.value:
The main hypotheses for this study are as follows:

H1: Individuals will have a higher WTP to mitigate risks perceived to be less-voluntary
H2: Individuals will have a higher WTP to mitigate risks perceived to be less-controllable

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The experimental design for this study is based off of the framework set up in Savage (1993), resulting in the attached survey.  Participants for the survey will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). The survey is laid out as follows; first, individuals will be asked their age, to be later used as a control during analysis.  Age was selected as the only relevant control for this study based on the results in Savage (1993) concerning the effects of demographics on WTP, where it is found that only age significantly influences WTP across all hazards.

Following this control, respondents will proceed to the allocation section of the survey.  In this section, respondents are asked to imagine they are participating in a referendum to decide how to split a government research budget between research to mitigate 4 different hazards, selected to invoke a wide range of perceptions of voluntary and control factors; pancreatic cancer, lung cancer, car accidents, and home fires.  Individuals' responses to this will take the form of allocating different percentages of the budget to each risk, with the requirement that the total adds up to 100%.  Initially, a separate note highlighted in red was included with this question to ask respondents to assume that research towards mitigating each hazard is identically efficient at spending money towards saving lives, in other words, 1% of the budget would save the same number of lives regardless of which hazard it is put towards.  However, this note was removed after pilot tests of the survey showed that participants interpreted this note as meaning there was a “correct” answer; to allocate budget evenly between the hazards.  Instead, the question was rephrased to contain this information about equal cost-efficiency in a less attention-grabbing manner.

After submitting their allocation, respondents then move on to the risk characteristics section of the survey.  In this section, individuals rate each hazard on a 7-point scale for each risk characteristic.  These characteristics include (and are asked in the following order) how at risk they believe themselves to personally be to a hazard, how voluntary they believe exposure to the hazard is, how controllable the consequences of the hazard are once an individual is exposed to it, how informed they feel about each hazard, and how much dread they feel about the hazard.  During the initial pilot tests of the survey, the order in which individuals were asked to consider these characteristics was randomized, however it was decided to designate a specific order to clarify what should be factored into each characteristic.  For example, individuals’ answers for how personally at risk they believe themselves to be to a hazard should not factor into their rating for the dread factor, so the survey is ordered so that individuals must first separately consider how personally at risk they are to a hazard, before rating the dread factor.

At the end of the survey, a unique ID is displayed to the respondent, with instructions for them to copy and paste it into AMT.  This allows for survey responses in Qualtrics to be connected back to the AMT platform to prevent duplicate responses and allow for compensation to be paid out.

In addition to 3 in-person pilot tests, this survey was piloted on the AMT platform with 9 respondents prior to the posting of the full study.  The responses from the pilot run will not be included in analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will be collected via an online survey created and hosted on the Qualtrics platform (attached).  Respondents to the survey will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT), with each respondent receiving compensation of $0.20 for their response (amounting to ~$5/hour).  The recruitment pool for respondents will be narrowed to only respondents living within the United States.  On the AMT platform, the survey will be displayed with the title “(3 Minute Survey) Research Funding Referendum” with the description “3 minute survey: Referendum on how to split a research budget between different applications”.  Potential respondents browsing the platform will be able to see the title and description before choosing to participate in the survey, but no other information.

In order to improve data quality, mainly by preventing duplicate responses, the AMT request will be created using the MTurk Pro toolbox from CloudResearch.  This toolbox allows for blocking of multiple responses from the same IP address.

The survey will be posted to the AMT platform on 3/18/20 and will be open for responses for 25 days (i.e. closing on 4/12/20).  During this period of data collection, none of the data will be observed or analyzed.  Analysis of the data will only begin at the end of this time frame or once the stopping rule is met.

q13.value: The target sample size for this study is set at N=750.  This simply consists of 750 individuals in total responding to the survey.

q14.value:
A number of factors influenced the decision of how to set the target sample size.  The first was comparability to the main literature after which this study is modeled, Savage (1993).  Savage (1993) had a sample size of approximately N=914.  Considering this, a goal was established to achieve a sample size as close to, if not exceeding, that of Savage (1993).  The second main consideration was budgetary constraints.  After establishing an estimate of the time required to complete the survey (~3 minutes), $0.20 per response was identified as an acceptable reward for respondents recruited through AMT.  With a reward set at this level, factoring in AMT’s commission, the cost of 750 responses comes out to $232.50 including CloudResearch Pro features to prevent duplicate IP addresses, exhausting the budget for this study.

The exclusion of the CloudResearch pro features preventing duplicate ID addresses would free up $52.50 of budget, allowing for an increase in sample size, however due to concerns about data quality without these features, the improved data quality is considered to outweigh the cost of reduced sample size. Although N=750 is below the sample size of Savage (1993), it is a high enough number to make comparison between the two studies viable.

q15.value: The survey will close, and respondents will cease to be recruited from AMT once one of two conditions is met.  These conditions are that 750 responses have been accumulated, or 25 days have elapsed since the survey was opened and posted to AMT.

question.value:
Following the procedure used in Savage (1993), responses to the question asking individuals to rate each hazard in terms of how well-informed they believe themselves to be about it on a 7-point scale will be transformed by subtracting 8 from each response.  The rationale for this is that in the phrasing of the question, a response of 7 indicates that an individual feels well-informed about the hazard, which is, as put by Savage, “the reverse of the other questions where the ‘worst’ outcome corresponded to 7.”

Additionally, when conducting the third regression model and analysis of the consensus on risk characteristics amongst the population, responses to each of the questions asking individuals to rate risk characteristics will be adjusted for individual response scaling.  Each individual’s mean response value for each variable will be subtracted from each observation.  The rationale behind this and the specifics of where it will be employed are detailed in the Analysis Plan.

The main outcome variable will be WTP.  This variable measures the percentage of the total budget allocated to each hazard in the allocation portion of the questionnaire.

Additionally, a variable will be measured for the rating of each risk characteristic on a 7-point scale for each hazard.  These characteristics are personal risk level, voluntariness, controllability, dread, and “unknown”.

Lastly, respondent’s age will be included as a control variable.

Analysis will consist of 3 main stages.  The first stage addresses the issue of potential correlation between the dread and control factor variables, as highlighted by previous literature Slovic, Fischhoff, and Lichtenstein (1980) and Savage (1993).  This is important to address, as a key difference between this study and Savage (1993) is that Savage chooses to exclude voluntary and control factors from his analysis based on their correlation with dread.  In order to assess the level of correlation, a correlation table showing correlations between all risk characteristic responses will be produced, modeled off of Table 3 in Fox-Glassman & Weber (2016).  If in this correlation table the correlation between dread and control factor is greater than 0.5, a “horse race” between dread and control factor will be conducted to determine which will be included in the following regression analyses.  Within the “horse race”, the p-value threshold for statistical significance is set at p < 0.05.

The first step of the “horse race” will be a regression with WTP as the outcome variable, using dread and control factor as explanatory variables alongside the age control variable (this is shown as equation (1) in the attached supplement PDF).  If the regression results show both dread and control factor to have significant effects, both will be included in the later regressions.  If the regression results show only one of the variables to have a significant effect, the other will be excluded from the later regressions.  If neither variable has a significant effect, the next step will be to test these variables one-by-one.  This one-by-one testing will consist of 2 regressions, each with WTP as the outcome variable and one of either dread or control factor as explanatory variable alongside the age control (shown as equation (2) in the supplement PDF).  If these regressions show both variables to have significant effects, the variable with the smaller magnitude of effect will be excluded from the later regressions.  If only one variable is shown to have significant effects, the other will be excluded from the later regressions.  If neither variable is shown to have significant effects, both will be excluded from future regressions.

Following the “horse race”, the second stage of analysis will be comprised of 3 OLS models assessing the relationship between the risk characteristics and WTP.  These models are based off of equations 2, 3, and 5 from Savage (1993), modified to include the additional risk characteristic variables assessed in this study.  The equations for these 3 models can be found in the attached supplement PDF.  Estimations were set as semi-log-linear OLS due to theory behind the relationship between WTP and disutility from hazard characteristics, and because the dependent variable may take the value of 0 (Savage (1993)).

The first model, shown as equation (3) in the attached PDF offers analysis of the effects of risk characteristics on WTP across individuals for each hazard.  In other words, this will consist of one regression for each of the 4 hazards, with 21 explanatory variables each.

The second model, shown as equation (4) in the attached PDF analyzes the effects of risk characteristics across individuals and hazards.  This will consist of one regression with one explanatory variable for each of the 5 risk characteristics.

The final model, shown as equation (5) in the attached PDF consists of the same analysis as the second model, while adjusting for individual response scaling in the rating of risk characteristics.  In practice, this means that panel data techniques will be used, subtracting each individual’s mean response value for that variable from each observation.
  
The final stage of analysis will be geared towards assessing the level of consensus among the population on perceptions of risk characteristics.  This will consist of a table showing means and measures of variability (standard deviation, variance) of responses to risk characteristic questions, first in absolute terms, and then after adjustment for individual response scaling, as specified above.  Additionally, dispersion of responses on perceived risk characteristics will be graphically represented in box plots, both before and after adjustment for individual response scaling.

In order to assess whether the 2 hypotheses designated earlier are supported, the following criteria will be used:

H1: In the first model, for each hazard, if the corresponding coefficient for that hazard and the voluntary factor is negative and meets significance thresholds set out in Inference Criteria section, the hypothesis will be considered to be supported, but only necessarily for that specific hazard.  In the 2nd and 3rd models, if the coefficient for the voluntary factor is negative and meets significance thresholds set out in the Inference Criteria section, the hypothesis will be considered to be supported, and will be considered to be robust if this condition is met in both models.

H2: If the control factor is left in the model after the “horse race”, the same criteria for assessing H1 will be used, replacing voluntary factor with control factor.  If control factor is excluded and dread factor is included after the “horse race”, the same criteria for assessing H1 will be used, replacing voluntary factor with dread, however if conditions are met, this result will only be considered suggestive of H2.  If both dread and control factor are excluded from analysis after the “horse race”, results for H2 will be considered inconclusive.

q20.value: Where applicable, responses to risk characteristic questions will be adjusted to account for individual response scaling, as detailed above.

q21.value: Regression results will be interpreted as conclusions based on significance thresholds.  Any results meeting the threshold of p < 0.005 will be considered robust, and any results meeting the threshold of p < 0.05 will be considered suggestive.  These thresholds are set based on Benjamin et al (2017).

q22.value: Any survey responses which have not completed all 8 questions will be excluded from analysis.

q23.value: In order to prevent the collection of incomplete data, the Qualtrics questionnaire has been set up so that an individual cannot submit a response without completing the survey in its entirety.  If an individual does not complete and submit a response, they will not receive compensation from AMT.

q24.value:
Exploratory analysis will consist of interpreting the results of the final stage of analysis, assessing consensus on perceived risk characteristics across the population.  This analysis will be considered exploratory as there will not be hypotheses for these results set out in advance, due to lack of previous literature in this area.

The exploratory analysis will specifically look at measures of variance of responses to the risk characteristic questions on the survey for each risk characteristic, and explore which ones of these are notably high or low, as well as how they compare to each other.  The importance of these comparisons is the implications they may have for the level of subjectivity of these risk characteristics.

Age was selected as the only relevant control for this study based on the results in Savage (1993) concerning the effects of demographics on WTP, where it is found that only age significantly influences WTP across all hazards.

Following this control, respondents will proceed to the allocation section of the survey.  In this section, respondents are asked to imagine they are participating in a referendum to decide how to split a government research budget between research to mitigate 4 different hazards, selected to invoke a wide range of perceptions of voluntary and control factors; pancreatic cancer, lung cancer, car accidents, and home fires.  Individuals' responses to this will take the form of allocating different percentages of the budget to each risk, with the requirement that the total adds up to 100%.  Initially, a separate note highlighted in red was included with this question to ask respondents to assume that research towards mitigating each hazard is identically efficient at spending money towards saving lives, in other words, 1% of the budget would save the same number of lives regardless of which hazard it is put towards.  However, this note was removed after pilot tests of the survey showed that participants interpreted this note as meaning there was a “correct” answer; to allocate budget evenly between the hazards.  Instead, the question was rephrased to contain this information about equal cost-efficiency in a less attention-grabbing manner.

After submitting their allocation, respondents then move on to the risk characteristics section of the survey.  In this section, individuals rate each hazard on a 7-point scale for each risk characteristic.  These characteristics include (and are asked in the following order) how at risk they believe themselves to personally be to a hazard, how voluntary they believe exposure to the hazard is, how controllable the consequences of the hazard are once an individual is exposed to it, how informed they feel about each hazard, and how much dread they feel about the hazard.  During the initial pilot tests of the survey, the order in which individuals were asked to consider these characteristics was randomized, however it was decided to designate a specific order to clarify what should be factored into each characteristic.  For example, individuals’ answers for how personally at risk they believe themselves to be to a hazard should not factor into their rating for the dread factor, so the survey is ordered so that individuals must first separately consider how personally at risk they are to a hazard, before rating the dread factor.

At the end of the survey, a unique ID is displayed to the respondent, with instructions for them to copy and paste it into AMT.  This allows for survey responses in Qualtrics to be connected back to the AMT platform to prevent duplicate responses and allow for compensation to be paid out.

In addition to 3 in-person pilot tests, this survey was piloted on the AMT platform with 9 respondents prior to the posting of the full study.  The responses from the pilot run will not be included in analysis.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Data will be collected via an online survey created and hosted on the Qualtrics platform (attached).  Respondents to the survey will be recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT), with each respondent receiving compensation of $0.20 for their response (amounting to ~$5/hour).  The recruitment pool for respondents will be narrowed to only respondents living within the United States.  On the AMT platform, the survey will be displayed with the title “(3 Minute Survey) Research Funding Referendum” with the description “3 minute survey: Referendum on how to split a research budget between different applications”.  Potential respondents browsing the platform will be able to see the title and description before choosing to participate in the survey, but no other information.

In order to improve data quality, mainly by preventing duplicate responses, the AMT request will be created using the MTurk Pro toolbox from CloudResearch.  This toolbox allows for blocking of multiple responses from the same IP address.

The survey will be posted to the AMT platform on 3/18/20 and will be open for responses for 25 days (i.e. closing on 4/12/20).  During this period of data collection, none of the data will be observed or analyzed.  Analysis of the data will only begin at the end of this time frame or once the stopping rule is met.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Following the procedure used in Savage (1993), responses to the question asking individuals to rate each hazard in terms of how well-informed they believe themselves to be about it on a 7-point scale will be transformed by subtracting 8 from each response.  The rationale for this is that in the phrasing of the question, a response of 7 indicates that an individual feels well-informed about the hazard, which is, as put by Savage, “the reverse of the other questions where the ‘worst’ outcome corresponded to 7.”

Additionally, when conducting the third regression model and analysis of the consensus on risk characteristics amongst the population, responses to each of the questions asking individuals to rate risk characteristics will be adjusted for individual response scaling.  Each individual’s mean response value for each variable will be subtracted from each observation.  The rationale behind this and the specifics of where it will be employed are detailed in the Analysis Plan.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The main outcome variable will be WTP.  This variable measures the percentage of the total budget allocated to each hazard in the allocation portion of the questionnaire.

Additionally, a variable will be measured for the rating of each risk characteristic on a 7-point scale for each hazard.  These characteristics are personal risk level, voluntariness, controllability, dread, and “unknown”.

Lastly, respondent’s age will be included as a control variable.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Analysis will consist of 3 main stages.  The first stage addresses the issue of potential correlation between the dread and control factor variables, as highlighted by previous literature Slovic, Fischhoff, and Lichtenstein (1980) and Savage (1993).  This is important to address, as a key difference between this study and Savage (1993) is that Savage chooses to exclude voluntary and control factors from his analysis based on their correlation with dread.  In order to assess the level of correlation, a correlation table showing correlations between all risk characteristic responses will be produced, modeled off of Table 3 in Fox-Glassman & Weber (2016).  If in this correlation table the correlation between dread and control factor is greater than 0.5, a “horse race” between dread and control factor will be conducted to determine which will be included in the following regression analyses.  Within the “horse race”, the p-value threshold for statistical significance is set at p < 0.05.

The first step of the “horse race” will be a regression with WTP as the outcome variable, using dread and control factor as explanatory variables alongside the age control variable (this is shown as equation (1) in the attached supplement PDF).  If the regression results show both dread and control factor to have significant effects, both will be included in the later regressions.  If the regression results show only one of the variables to have a significant effect, the other will be excluded from the later regressions.  If neither variable has a significant effect, the next step will be to test these variables one-by-one.  This one-by-one testing will consist of 2 regressions, each with WTP as the outcome variable and one of either dread or control factor as explanatory variable alongside the age control (shown as equation (2) in the supplement PDF).  If these regressions show both variables to have significant effects, the variable with the smaller magnitude of effect will be excluded from the later regressions.  If only one variable is shown to have significant effects, the other will be excluded from the later regressions.  If neither variable is shown to have significant effects, both will be excluded from future regressions.

Following the “horse race”, the second stage of analysis will be comprised of 3 OLS models assessing the relationship between the risk characteristics and WTP.  These models are based off of equations 2, 3, and 5 from Savage (1993), modified to include the additional risk characteristic variables assessed in this study.  The equations for these 3 models can be found in the attached supplement PDF.  Estimations were set as semi-log-linear OLS due to theory behind the relationship between WTP and disutility from hazard characteristics, and because the dependent variable may take the value of 0 (Savage (1993)).

The first model, shown as equation (3) in the attached PDF offers analysis of the effects of risk characteristics on WTP across individuals for each hazard.  In other words, this will consist of one regression for each of the 4 hazards, with 21 explanatory variables each.

The second model, shown as equation (4) in the attached PDF analyzes the effects of risk characteristics across individuals and hazards.  This will consist of one regression with one explanatory variable for each of the 5 risk characteristics.

The final model, shown as equation (5) in the attached PDF consists of the same analysis as the second model, while adjusting for individual response scaling in the rating of risk characteristics.  In practice, this means that panel data techniques will be used, subtracting each individual’s mean response value for that variable from each observation.
  
The final stage of analysis will be geared towards assessing the level of consensus among the population on perceptions of risk characteristics.  This will consist of a table showing means and measures of variability (standard deviation, variance) of responses to risk characteristic questions, first in absolute terms, and then after adjustment for individual response scaling, as specified above.  Additionally, dispersion of responses on perceived risk characteristics will be graphically represented in box plots, both before and after adjustment for individual response scaling.

In order to assess whether the 2 hypotheses designated earlier are supported, the following criteria will be used:

H1: In the first model, for each hazard, if the corresponding coefficient for that hazard and the voluntary factor is negative and meets significance thresholds set out in Inference Criteria section, the hypothesis will be considered to be supported, but only necessarily for that specific hazard.  In the 2nd and 3rd models, if the coefficient for the voluntary factor is negative and meets significance thresholds set out in the Inference Criteria section, the hypothesis will be considered to be supported, and will be considered to be robust if this condition is met in both models.

H2: If the control factor is left in the model after the “horse race”, the same criteria for assessing H1 will be used, replacing voluntary factor with control factor.  If control factor is excluded and dread factor is included after the “horse race”, the same criteria for assessing H1 will be used, replacing voluntary factor with dread, however if conditions are met, this result will only be considered suggestive of H2.  If both dread and control factor are excluded from analysis after the “horse race”, results for H2 will be considered inconclusive.

attributes.title: The impact of detail oriented level on pain management strategy and recovery.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
The impact of detail-oriented level on pain management strategy and recovery. 
A mixed-methods study trying to use a multilevel perspective method in order to build a greater understanding of detail-oriented trait and its possible influences in pain management among individuals.

other.value: The study is an explanatory sequential design. Therefore, qualitative data will be involved but only to support and give reasoning behind the quantitative element. The data will be collected for qualitative through input text boxes in the online questionnaire and these will be transcribed and analysed using thematic analysis from Braun and Clarke (2006) as mentioned above.

sample.value: The goal is to accumulate at least 100 participants as this would mean we are greatly over the required amount for a moderate effect throughout the study on 0.8 power level and an alpha of .05. Estimated using A’priori power analysis.

analyses.value: The quantitative analysis is currently set to incorporate two separate simple linear regressions. The first will incorporate ‘Detail Oriented level’ (Predictor) and ‘Pain management score’ (Outcome). The second will differ with ‘Pain Recovery score’ as the outcome. The qualitative element will incorporate thematic analysis from Braun and Clarke (2006). The answers to questions will be transcribed and read through looking for codes of similar nature. These codes will allow themes to be created which will be used to supplement quantitative results.

outliers.value: The data will be screened through scatter plots and histograms to remove possible outliers in data. Data which is found to be specifically out of place in the data screening will be removed. Observatory screening where it is clear the participant was not engaging with the study, for example, the same answer is given for each question and finishing questionnaire in an unreasonable low amount of time will be removed.

dependent.value: The outcome variables will be ‘Pain management score’ and ‘Pain recovery score’. The first will be measured using a subscale version of the ‘The Pain Stages of change questionnaire’ and the second using ‘fifth vital sign’ tool.

conditions.value: All participants will be taking part in all elements and no different conditions will be present to describe.

hypothesis.value: This study will set out to look directly at the impact detail-oriented trait has on an individual’s pain management strategy and recovery period from a period of pain. With the hypothesis that the multilevel perspective method used will show detail-oriented individuals having stronger pain management with data on how it specifically allows for better recovery.

attributes.title: Asymmetric processing of upward- and downward-trending stock markets

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Asymmetric processing of upward- and downward-trending stock markets

other.value: We are attempting to replicate an already-collected sample of 33 participants, in which we observe the effects we specify in Question 2. Our objective is two-fold: to examine the robustness of our effect, and to generalize to a new population (the previous sample was collected in Texas, the registered one will be conducted online).

sample.value: Based on power analyses conducted on data collected previously in our lab, the required sample would be of 150 participants (alpha=0.05, 1-beta=0.95, effect size 0.3). To account for drop-out and exclusion (see above), we will collect data from 165 participants.

analyses.value:
Data of each market’s initial and final trials will be excluded, because in the trial there is no preceding investment decision, and in the final trial there is no immediately-following investment decision. The remaining 180 trials will be entered into a multiple linear regression, conducted on each participant’s choices separately. The regression will consist of 9 predictors: previous bet (b+ and b-), previous market (r+ and r-), and previous outcome (b+r+,b+r-, b-r-, and b-r+).
To compile an across-participant coefficient, we will normalize each individual’s coefficients by their respective standard error, and the across-participant coefficients will be compared to zero using single-sample t-tests. 
To test the relationship between the effect of market and the effect of outcomes we will perform four Pearson correlations: (1) between r+ and b-r+ coefficients, (2) between r+ and b+r+ coefficients, (3) between r- and b-r- coefficients, and (4) between r- and b+r- coefficients.
We will also look at overall betting behavior by conducting a one-sample t-test of all bets placed compared to a mean of zero. We expect to find a bias toward positive bets.

outliers.value:
Following the task, participants will complete a comprehension quiz. Failure on the quiz (<50% correct responses) will result in exclusion from analyses. 
Betting behavior that is invariant would be impossible to model, since regression analysis relies on that variance. Therefore, participants whose responses are >90% the same (e.g., someone always betting all-in, +100) would be excluded.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable is participants’ bets on a stock market sequential investment task. Participants will make investment decisions bt (-100%∼100% of current portfolio, in increments of 10%). At 0%, none of the participant’s portfolio would be allocated to the market; at 100% and -100%, all would be subject to market fluctuations, depending on its direction. 
Each participant will play a total of 10 markets, and each market will consist of 20 trials. The presentation order of markets will be counterbalanced between participants.

conditions.value:
There will be no between-participant manipulation. Participants can choose to invest (b+) or short-sell (b-). The market fluctuates either up (r+) or down (r-), resulting in one of four potential outcomes for each trial: invest & win (b+r+), invest & lose (b+r-), short & win (b-r-) or short & lose (b-r+).
Thus, although participants are not assigned to different conditions, each trial belongs to one of four outcome-conditions and one of two market-conditions.

hypothesis.value:
We examine whether investing and short-selling behaviors (b+ and b-, respectively) are similar for positive- and negative-trending markets (r+ and r-, respectively). Specifically, we are asking whether the influence that previous market fluctuations (r) and outcomes (b*r) have on subsequent bets depends on the market's direction.
Based on previous data collected in the lab, we hypothesize that the answer is yes.
Specific hypotheses: 
1) r+ (positive market fluctuations) will not affect subsequent bets - n.s. coefficient
2) r- (negative market fluctuations) will affect subsequent bets - significant positive coefficient
3) b+r+ outcomes (invest & win) will affect subsequent bets - significant negative coefficient
4) b-r+ outcomes (short & lose) will affect subsequent bets - significant negative coefficient
5) b+r- outcomes (invest & lose) will not affect subsequent bets - n.s coefficient
6) b-r- outcomes (short & win) will not affect subsequent bets - n.s coefficient

For completeness, we list low-interest hypotheses of other components of the regression analysis:
7) b+ (invest) would affect subsequent bets -  significant positive coefficient
8) b- (short-sell) would affect subsequent bets - significant positive coefficient
9) intercept - we expect a positive intercept, corresponding to an average positive bet.
